_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Urethane and Other Foam Product (except Polystyrene) Manufacturing

_accidents.CI_OtherType: Repaired tank will have a rupture disk and safety vents.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EPA's Risk Management Plan

Executive Summary

for 

Woodbridge CorporationA?s 

Atlanta Foam Plant



1. Accidental Release Prevention & Emergency Response Policies



The Atlanta Foam Plant, as part of the Woodbridge group of companies, believes the health & safety of its employees and the protection of the natural environment, is of the utmost concern in the operation of its business.  We are committed to operating & maintaining all of our processes in a safe & responsible manner.



It is our policy to:



Comply with all applicable laws, regulations, and standards.

Review and assess our operations for the purpose of making health, safety, & environmental improvements.



Our complete Health, Safety, & Environmental policy statement, signed by our plant manager, is posted in the lobby of our facility.



We use a combination of prevention programs and emergency response planning, which are described later in this document, to help ensure the safety of our employees, the public, and to ensure protection of the environment.  Our Plant Manager has the overall responsibility for ensuring that our facility operates in a safe and reliable manner.  This responsibility includes overseeing the implementation of the elements of our risk management program.  To ensure that our risk management program is appropriately developed and implemented, our Plant Manager has assigned the role of RMP Coordinator to a staff member with the background, training, and experience necessary to manage the program.  The RMP Coordinator, acting with the authority delegated directly from the Plant Manager, is responsible for coordinating the development, implementation and integration of the RMP elements as is required under Section 68.15 of the RMP rule.  



2. The Stationary Source & Regulated Substances Handled



The primary purpose of the Atlanta Foam Plant is to produce polyurethane foam seat cushions for the automotive industry.  The foam is made by high pressure mixing of chemicals a

s they are poured into a mold that is attached by carrier to a continuously moving line.  The mold then moves through a curing oven.  Upon exiting the oven, the foam pads are removed from the mold, vacuum or mechanically crushed, trimmed, and prepared for shipment to customers.



Toluene Diisocyanate (TDI), which is regulated by EPA's risk management program rule, is one of the reactants required to manufacture polyurethane foam.  TDI is received at the plant by railcar and tanker truck, and is stored in 2 tanks located in the contained bulk storage tank room.  The TDI is then transferred to the process utilizing a computer-controlled system.



Access to the site is restricted to authorized facility employees, management personnel, and contractors.  The maximum amount of TDI that can be stored at this facility is 210,000 pounds.



3. The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and the Specific Prevention Steps



We take a systematic, proactive approach to preventing accidental releases of chemicals.  Our management systems for our TDI process address each of the key features of successful prevention programs including:



Contractor Awareness

Hot Work Permitting

Monthly Workplace Inspection by members of the JHS&E Team

Safety Information

Hazard Reviews of our Processes

Operating Procedures

Training

Equipment Maintenance Programs

RMP Compliance Audits

Accident/Incident Investigation



In addition, we have an established Isocyanate Control Program that outlines both the hazards of handling toluene diisocyanate and the controls that are in place to reduce those hazards.  Controls are in place to reduce exposure to employees, the community, and the environment.



These listed individual elements of our prevention program work together to prevent accidental chemical releases.  Our company and our employees are committed to the standard that these management systems are setup for the way we conduct business, and we have specific accountabilities and c

ontrols to ensure that we are meeting our own high standards for accident prevention. 



4. Five-year Accident History



The Atlanta Foam Plant has only had one instance that required reporting under EPA's five-year accident history report. This was an overpressurization of a TDI tank during filling. The accident was handled promptly on-site to limit health and environmental impacts. Due to the quick response, no TDI was released to the environment and no employees were injured. New controls will be installed with the repair of the tank to help prevent a recurrence of the accident, and the facility will strive to ensure that no additional accidents occur in the future.



5. The Emergency Response Plan



As a non-responding site to the RMP chemical, the facility meets the Emergency Action Plan requirements and addresses them in the site Integrated Contingency Plan (ICP). Actions that are taken by facility personnel and addressed in the ICP include activation of the local emergency notification system and calling 911 from a safe location [29 CFR 1910.38(c)(1)] and directing an evacuation, including exit route assignments [29 CFR 1910.38(c)(2)]. All employees are trained to assist other employees in a safe and orderly evacuation [29 CFR 1910.38(c)(2)]. Should the scope of any incident exceed the capability of our staff, such as a large release, the employee discovering emergency shall follow the protocol provided in the ICP to notify facility personnel, isolate the covered process if safe to do so, evacuate the facility and perform headcount at the designated muster point, and contact emergency responders. We maintain an ICP, which consolidates the various federal, state, and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning.  Our program provides essential planning and training to effectively protect workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.  As our LEPC and SEPC are one and the same, we have coordinated our program with the

local fire department.  A representative group from the fire department routinely visits this plant to discuss how to respond to a release of TDI.  We have also given local hospitals information regarding medical treatment for exposure to TDI.



6. Planned Changes to Improve Safety



At this time we continue to maintain our current safety management systems.  We continually evaluate training and operational procedures and will be implementing controls with the repair of the TDI tank.
